title: My Message to Women About Substance Abuse

content: When you think of someone addicted to drugs, you might think of someone on the streets, doing whatever they can to get their fix. Chances are your imaginary person is dirty, living life solely for the drug that holds them prisoner.
Did a nicely dressed woman come to mind? One that’s living a normal life, maybe with kids and a family, maybe without? Doubt it.
Many people will think of a man when they think of someone struggling with drug use, possibly for the simple fact that men have higher rates of use or dependence on substances than women do.

However, according to the National Institute on Drug Abuse , “Women are just as likely as men to develop a substance use disorder. In addition, women may be more susceptible to craving and relapse, which are key phases of the addiction cycle.”

They go on to say that “research has shown that women often use drugs differently, respond to drugs differently, and can have unique obstacles to effective treatment as simple as not being able to find childcare or being prescribed treatment that has not been adequately tested on women.”

content: Women and men are different, but substances are not. They are addictive no matter who is taking them, and while they may affect men differently than they do women, the fact remains that they’re a problem.

You may start using substances for a whole list of reasons. Maybe you were prescribed them by a doctor, maybe you lost someone you love and just needed something to help with the pain, or maybe life and the many stresses you deal with are just too much sometimes.
Whatever your reason, the fact remains that substances don’t discriminate. You are just as likely to become addicted to something as the next person, no matter your station in life, let alone gender.

Before I misused opioids, I felt like I was the least likely candidate you could think of for someone who struggled with addiction, painkillers, or anything else.  I was a young girl from a good family, preparing for college with the world ahead of me.

content: But life is unexpected, and when things happened that I wasn’t prepared for, I struggled. When I was put on opioids for an indefinite amount of time, I struggled. When I found myself addicted and scared of what the future held, I struggled.

And even once I got clean, I struggled. I had such high expectations for myself and for my life, and instead of seeing my time using opioids as a brief period of my life, I saw it as a roadblock to future progression.

I felt I’d failed. I didn’t live up to the expectations I had for myself, and even though I was clean now, this was not the way I’d planned for my life to go. I screwed it up, and there was no getting that life plan back.

It took a long time (years, in fact) for me to realize that just because the plan I had for my life didn’t pan out, it didn’t mean that my life was over. It didn’t mean I couldn’t form a new plan and still move forward.

content: My mental image of myself was disrupted. But it was eventually reformed and made into something just as good, if not better than what I’d envisioned before.
My situation wasn’t unique. It can happen to anyone, young or old, White or Black, male or female.
